none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from A. J. Rose, July 11, 1890
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from A. J. Rose, July 11, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 3 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

State Agricultural and Mechanical College
OF TEXAS.
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

A. J. ROSE, President Board of Directors, Salado Texas.
T. M. SCOTT, Agent of the Board, College Station, Texas.
LOUIS L. McINNIS, Secretary and Treasurer, College Station, Texas.

[Dateline]

Salado, Texas, July 11th 1880

[Address]

Louis L McInnis
College Station Txas

[Salutation]

Dear prof

[Body]

at 230 P.M, I open and read
yours of the 8th I Write hurriadly. Can say
that if I can not come will wire you Tuesday
morning better set Widesday to meet you
I am worked down though my appearance does
not show it and have more on hand than
seems possible for me to get through with
now and during this and next month.
now if I dont wire you Tuesday and nothing
gets in my way I will meet you at
Driskal Hotel Tuesday evening, I
am Yours Truly

[Signature]

A. J. Rose

**Transcription Analysis and Text Generation** Okay, here's what I've got, breaking down this document meticulously. This is a letter, and it looks like I need to make a full transcription. First, I have to analyze the overall structure. It's on some official stationery, which is fun. [Header] * The header is a big deal, of course. It's the "State Agricultural and Mechanical College" and then "OF TEXAS." with some flourish, and then "(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)". There is a small printed block of names and titles: A. J. Rose (President), T. M. Scott (Agent of the Board), and Louis L. McInnis (Secretary and Treasurer), all with locations. It’s pretty standard for the time. [Dateline] * The dateline is "Salado, Texas," and then "July 11th" is handwritten. And then the year. The printed part is "18__", but the handwritten part is tricky, the handwritten part has a loop, definitely looks like "80" at first, though also like "90". Let's think. The letterhead looks old. Let's compare "80" with the '8' in "8th". The '8' is formed similarly. So 1880, I'll transcribe as "1880". [Address] * The addressee is Louis L McInnis, and the location is "College Station Txas". Looks like "Txas" not "Texas". [Salutation] * The salutation is "Dear prof". "prof" is lowercase. [Body] * The body is handwritten and full of cursive. I need to transcribe it carefully, word by word. * "at 2 30 P.M, I open and read" * "yours of the 8th I Write hurriadly. Can say" * "that if I can not come will wire you Tuesday" * "morning" is inserted above "Tuesday". "better set Widesday to meet you" - This is where the core of the letter's intent comes out. It also looks like "Wensday" or "Widerday". Given context, It *means* "Wednesday", but it *looks like* "Widesday" and the instructions are to be accurate. * "I am worked down though my appearance does" * "not show it and have more on hand than" * "seems possible for me to get through with" * "now and during this and next month." * "Now if I dont wire you Tuesday and nothing" * "gets in my way I will meet you at" * "Driskal Hotel Tuesday evening, I" * "am Yours Truly" * "A. J. Rose" [Signature] * The closing is "Am Yours Truly" and "A. J. Rose." * Okay, I'll put it all together while maintaining the structure of the letter. This is like a very literal, textual representation. Here is the resulting transcription of the letter: [Header] State Agricultural and Mechanical College
OF TEXAS.
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)
A. J. ROSE, President Board of Directors, Salado Texas.
T. M. SCOTT, Agent of the Board, College Station, Texas.
LOUIS L. McINNIS, Secretary and Treasurer, College Station, Texas. [Dateline] Salado, Texas, July 11th 1880 [Address] Louis L McInnis
College Station Txas [Salutation] Dear prof [Body] at 230 P.M, I open and read
yours of the 8th I Write hurriadly. Can say
that if I can not come will wire you Tuesday
morning better set Widesday to meet you
I am worked down though my appearance does
not show it and have more on hand than
seems possible for me to get through with
now and during this and next month.
Now if I dont wire you Tuesday and nothing
gets in my way I will meet you at
Driskal Hotel Tuesday evening, I
am Yours Truly [Signature] A. J. Rose
